translated: Abhidharma-mahÄvibhÄá¹£Ä-Å›Ästra, fascicle 100
ninety-three
Composed by 500 great arhats and others
Tripiá¹­aka master Xuanzang respectfully received
If one abides in the prÄtimoká¹£a precepts,
Or does not abide in the prÄtimoká¹£a precepts,
There is good bodily and verbal expression that is not lost.
If one who abides in a wholesome mind dies,
They abandon the five aggregates of wholesome form and two indeterminate aggregates.
Some say,
They obtain the five aggregates of wholesome form and four indeterminate aggregates and two.
At that time, the five aggregates of wholesome form and one defiled aggregate and two indeterminate aggregates cease.
One aggregate of wholesome form and four defiled aggregates and two indeterminate aggregates are present.
If one who abides in an indeterminate mind dies,
They abandon the five aggregates of wholesome form and five indeterminate aggregates.
They obtain the four aggregates of wholesome form and two indeterminate aggregates.
At that time, two aggregates of wholesome form and one defiled aggregate and five indeterminate aggregates cease.
One aggregate of wholesome form and four defiled aggregates and two indeterminate aggregates are present.
If one originally does not abide in the prÄtimoká¹£a precepts,
one has no wholesome or neutral bodily or verbal manifest karma, even if one had it, it has already been lost.
If one who abides in a wholesome mind dies,
one abandons the four wholesome aggregates and two neutral aggregates.
Some say:
One obtains the four wholesome aggregates and two neutral aggregates.
Then at that time, the four wholesome aggregates, one defiled aggregate, and two neutral aggregates cease.
One wholesome aggregate, one defiled aggregate, and two neutral aggregates are present.
If one who abides in a neutral mind dies,
one abandons the four wholesome aggregates and five neutral aggregates.
One obtains the four wholesome aggregates and two neutral aggregates.
Then at that time, one wholesome aggregate, one defiled aggregate, and five neutral aggregates cease.
One wholesome aggregate, one defiled aggregate, and two neutral aggregates are present.
Those who die in the desire realm and are reborn in the second, third, or fourth meditative absorptions,
if they originally abide in the prÄtimoká¹£a precepts,
or if they do not abide in the prÄtimoká¹£a precepts,
and have wholesome bodily or verbal manifest karma that is not lost,ğŸ”½...
If one dies while abiding in a wholesome mind,
one abandons the five wholesome aggregates and five indeterminate aggregates,
and obtains four wholesome aggregates and two indeterminate aggregates.
At that time, the five wholesome aggregates, one defiled aggregate, and two indeterminate aggregates cease,
while one wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates are present.
If one dies while abiding in an indeterminate mind,
one abandons the five wholesome aggregates and five indeterminate aggregates,
and obtains four wholesome aggregates and two indeterminate aggregates.
At that time, two wholesome aggregates, one defiled aggregate, and five indeterminate aggregates cease,
while one wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates are present.
If one has not previously abided in the discipline of individual liberation,
and does not have wholesome bodily and verbal expressions, even if one had them, they have already been lost.
If one dies while abiding in a wholesome mind,
one abandons the five wholesome aggregates and five indeterminate aggregates,
and obtains four wholesome aggregates and two indeterminate aggregates.
At that time, four wholesome aggregates, one defiled aggregate, and two indeterminate aggregates cease,
When one wholesome aggregate and four defiled indeterminate aggregates are present,
if one ends one's life while abiding in an indeterminate mind,
one abandons five wholesome aggregates and five indeterminate aggregates,
and obtains four wholesome aggregates and two indeterminate aggregates.
At that time, one wholesome aggregate, one defiled aggregate, and five indeterminate aggregates cease,
while one wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates are present.
Those who end their lives in the desire realm and are reborn in the formless realm,
if they originally abide in the discipline of individual liberation,
or do not abide in the discipline of individual liberation,
but have wholesome bodily and verbal expressions that are not lost,
if they end their lives while abiding in a wholesome mind,
they abandon five wholesome aggregates and five indeterminate aggregates,
and obtain four wholesome aggregates and one indeterminate aggregate.
At that time, five wholesome aggregates, one defiled aggregate, and two indeterminate aggregates cease,
while one wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and one indeterminate aggregate are present.
If one ends one's life while abiding in an indeterminate mind,
one abandons five wholesome aggregates and five indeterminate aggregates,ğŸ”½and obtains four wholesome aggregates and one indeterminate aggregate.
One obtains the four wholesome aggregates and one indeterminate aggregate.
At that time, two wholesome aggregates, one defiled aggregate, and five indeterminate aggregates cease.
One wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and one indeterminate aggregate are present.
If one does not abide in the prÄtimoká¹£a precepts,
one may have no wholesome or unwholesome bodily or verbal expression, or if one has it, one may have already lost it.
If one who abides in wholesome thoughts dies,
one abandons five wholesome aggregates and five indeterminate aggregates.
One obtains four wholesome aggregates and one indeterminate aggregate.
At that time, four wholesome aggregates, one defiled aggregate, and two indeterminate aggregates cease.
One wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and one indeterminate aggregate are present.
If one who abides in indeterminate thoughts dies,
one abandons five wholesome aggregates and five indeterminate aggregates.
One obtains four wholesome aggregates and one indeterminate aggregate.
At that time, one wholesome aggregate, one defiled aggregate, and five indeterminate aggregates cease.
One wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and one indeterminate aggregate are present.
Those who die in the form realm and are reborn in the form realm,
Those who die in this stage and are reborn in this stage,
if they die with a wholesome mind,
they abandon two formless aggregates and two indeterminate aggregates,
and obtain two indeterminate aggregates.
At that time, the four wholesome aggregates, one defiled aggregate, and two indeterminate aggregates cease,
and one wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates manifest.
If they die with a defiled mind,
they abandon two indeterminate aggregates,
and obtain two indeterminate aggregates.
At that time, one wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates cease,
and one wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates manifest.
If they die with an indeterminate mind,
they abandon five indeterminate aggregates,
and obtain two indeterminate aggregates.
At that time, one wholesome aggregate, one defiled aggregate, and five indeterminate aggregates cease,
and one wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates manifest.
Those who die in the lower stages of the form realm and are reborn in the upper stages,
if they die with a wholesome mind,
They abandon the five wholesome aggregates and five indeterminate aggregates.
They obtain four wholesome aggregates and two indeterminate aggregates.
At that time, the four wholesome aggregates, one defiled aggregate, and two indeterminate aggregates cease.
One wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates are present.
If one dies while abiding in an indeterminate mind,
they abandon the five wholesome aggregates and five indeterminate aggregates.
They obtain four wholesome aggregates and two indeterminate aggregates.
Then at that time, one wholesome aggregate, one defiled aggregate, and five indeterminate aggregates cease.
One wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates are present.
Those who fall from the upper stages of the form realm and are reborn in the lower stages,
if they die while abiding in a wholesome mind,
they abandon the five wholesome aggregates and five indeterminate aggregates.
They obtain five wholesome aggregates, four defiled aggregates, and five indeterminate aggregates.
At that time, four wholesome aggregates, one defiled aggregate, and two indeterminate aggregates cease.
One wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates are present.
If they die while abiding in a defiled mind,
They abandon the five wholesome aggregates and the five indeterminate aggregates.
They obtain the five wholesome aggregates, four defiled aggregates, and five indeterminate aggregates.
At that time, one wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates cease.
One wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates manifest.
If one dies while abiding in an indeterminate mind,
they abandon the five wholesome aggregates and the five indeterminate aggregates.
They obtain the five wholesome aggregates, four defiled aggregates, and five indeterminate aggregates.
At that time, one wholesome aggregate, one defiled aggregate, and five indeterminate aggregates cease.
One wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates manifest.
Those who die in the form realm and are reborn in the desire realm,
if they die while abiding in a wholesome mind, they abandon the five wholesome aggregates and the five indeterminate aggregates.
They obtain four wholesome aggregates, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates.
Some say five.ğŸ”½At that time, four wholesome aggregates, one defiled aggregate, and two indeterminate aggregates cease.
One wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates manifest.
If one dies while dwelling in a defiled mind,
one abandons the five wholesome aggregates and five indeterminate aggregates,
and obtains four wholesome aggregates, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates.
Some say five.
At that time, one wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates cease,
and one wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates manifest.
If one dies while dwelling in an indeterminate mind,
one abandons the five wholesome aggregates and five indeterminate aggregates,
and obtains four wholesome aggregates, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates.
Some say five.
At that time, one wholesome aggregate, one defiled aggregate, and five indeterminate aggregates cease,
and one wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates manifest.
Those who die in the form realm and are reborn in the formless realm,
if they die while dwelling in a wholesome mind,
they abandon the five wholesome aggregates and five indeterminate aggregates,
and obtain four wholesome aggregates and one indeterminate aggregate.
At that time, four wholesome aggregates, one defiled aggregate, and two indeterminate aggregates cease,
When a wholesome aggregate and four defiled aggregates and one indeterminate aggregate appear in the present,
if one ends one's life while abiding in an indeterminate mind,
one abandons five wholesome aggregates and five indeterminate aggregates,
and obtains four wholesome aggregates and one indeterminate aggregate.
At that very moment, one wholesome aggregate, one defiled aggregate, and five indeterminate aggregates cease,
and one wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and one indeterminate aggregate appear in the present.
Those who end their lives in the formless realm and are reborn in the formless realm,
those who fall from this stage and are reborn in this stage,
if they end their lives while abiding in a wholesome mind,
they abandon one indeterminate aggregate and obtain one indeterminate aggregate.
At that very moment, four wholesome aggregates, one defiled aggregate, and one indeterminate aggregate cease,
and one wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and one indeterminate aggregate appear in the present.
If they end their lives while abiding in a defiled mind,
they abandon one indeterminate aggregate,
and obtain one indeterminate aggregate.
At that very moment, one wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and one indeterminate aggregate cease,
If one abiding in a neutral mind dies,
they abandon four neutral aggregates.
They obtain one neutral aggregate.
At that very moment, one wholesome aggregate, one defiled aggregate, and four neutral aggregates cease.
One wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and one neutral aggregate are present.
Those who die in the lower stages of the formless realm and are reborn in the upper stages,
if abiding in a wholesome mind at death,
they abandon four wholesome aggregates and one neutral aggregate.
They obtain four wholesome aggregates and one neutral aggregate.
At that very moment, four wholesome aggregates, one defiled aggregate, and one neutral aggregate cease.
One wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and one neutral aggregate are present.
If one abiding in a neutral mind dies,
they abandon four wholesome aggregates and four neutral aggregates.
They obtain four wholesome aggregates and one neutral aggregate.
At that very moment, one wholesome aggregate, one defiled aggregate, and four neutral aggregates cease.
When a wholesome aggregate and four defiled aggregates and one indeterminate aggregate appear in the present,
When one falls from the upper stages of the formless realm and is reborn in the lower stages,
If one ends one's life while abiding in a wholesome mind,
One abandons the wholesome aggregates and four indeterminate aggregates and one.
One obtains the wholesome aggregates and four defiled aggregates and one indeterminate aggregate.
Then at that time, the wholesome four aggregates, the defiled one aggregate, and the indeterminate one aggregate cease.
The wholesome one aggregate, the defiled four aggregates, and the indeterminate one aggregate appear in the present.
If one ends one's life while abiding in a defiled mind,
One abandons the wholesome aggregates and four indeterminate aggregates and one.
One obtains the wholesome aggregates and four defiled aggregates and one indeterminate aggregate.
Then at that time, the wholesome one aggregate, the defiled four aggregates, and the indeterminate one aggregate cease.
The wholesome one aggregate, the defiled four aggregates, and the indeterminate one aggregate appear in the present.
If one ends one's life while abiding in an indeterminate mind,ğŸ”½One abandons the wholesome aggregates and four indeterminate aggregates.
One obtains the wholesome aggregates and four defiled aggregates and one indeterminate aggregate.
Then at that time, one wholesome aggregate, one defiled aggregate, and four indeterminate aggregates cease.
One wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and one indeterminate aggregate appear in the present.
Those who die in the formless realm and are reborn in the desire realm,
if they die with a wholesome mind,
they abandon one wholesome aggregate, four indeterminate aggregates,
and obtain four wholesome aggregates, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates.
Some say five.
Then at that time, four wholesome aggregates, one defiled aggregate, and one indeterminate aggregate cease.
One wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates appear in the present.
If they die with a defiled mind,
they abandon one wholesome aggregate, four indeterminate aggregates,
and obtain four wholesome aggregates, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates.
Some say five.
Then at that time, one wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and one indeterminate aggregate cease.
One wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates appear in the present.
If they die with an indeterminate mind,
They abandon four wholesome aggregates and four indeterminate aggregates,
and obtain four wholesome aggregates, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates.
Some say there are five.
At that time, one wholesome aggregate, one defiled aggregate, and four indeterminate aggregates cease.
One wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates appear.
Those who die in the formless realm and are reborn in the form realm,
if they die with a wholesome mind,
they abandon four wholesome aggregates and one indeterminate aggregate,
and obtain five wholesome aggregates, four defiled aggregates, and five indeterminate aggregates.
At that time, four wholesome aggregates, one defiled aggregate, and one indeterminate aggregate cease.
One wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and two indeterminate aggregates appear.
If they die with a defiled mind,
they abandon four wholesome aggregates and one indeterminate aggregate,
and obtain five wholesome aggregates, four defiled aggregates, and five indeterminate aggregates.
At that time, one wholesome aggregate, four defiled aggregates, and one indeterminate aggregate cease.
When one with wholesome one aggregate and defiled four aggregates, and indeterminate two aggregates present,
if one dies while abiding in an indeterminate mind,
one abandons the wholesome aggregates four and indeterminate aggregates four,
and obtains the wholesome aggregates five, defiled aggregates four, and indeterminate aggregates five.
At that time, the wholesome one aggregate, defiled one aggregate, and indeterminate four aggregates cease,
and the wholesome one aggregate, defiled four aggregates, and indeterminate two aggregates are present.

Why do the latent tendencies of the desire realm not increase with respect to dharmas of the form realm? ... and so on at length.ğŸ”½Here is the text with the alignment mistakes fixed and the English translations updated to match the Sanskrit:
Why was this treatise composed?
The answer is: in order to bring certainty to the doubtful.
Namely, in the previous chapter on the aggregates of fetters and beings, it is said:
Ordinary beings in the desire realm have ninety-eight latent tendencies that increase and are bound by nine fetters,
ordinary beings in the form realm have sixty-two latent tendencies that increase and are bound by six fetters,
and ordinary beings in the formless realm have thirty-one latent tendencies that increase and are bound by six fetters.
Some may doubt this,
Ordinary beings in the desire realm are followed and increased by the latent tendencies of the form and formless realms.
Ordinary beings in the form realm are followed and increased by the latent tendencies of the formless realm.
In order to resolve this doubt,
it is shown that one who possesses them is not followed and increased by them.
That is to say, ordinary beings in the desire realm are only followed and increased by the latent tendencies of the desire realm, not by those of the form and formless realms.
Ordinary beings in the form realm are only followed and increased by the latent tendencies of the form realm, not by those of the formless realm.
For this reason, this treatise is composed.
Why do the latent tendencies in the desire realm not follow and increase with regard to dharmas in the form realm?
The answer is: because the realms would be confused and it would be impossible to establish the separation from desire-attachment.
As for the confusion of the realms,
it means that they would be both the desire realm and the form realm.
Then it would be impossible to say that the desire realm and the form realm are different.

As for it being impossible to establish the separation from desire-attachment,ğŸ”½it means that when one separates from craving in the desire realm, it is not called separation from the defilements of the desire realm.
When one separates from craving in the form realm, it is called separation from the defilements of the desire realm.
This is unreasonable.
Why do the latent afflictions in the desire realm not increase in the dharmas of the formless realm?
Answer: The realms would be mixed up.
And because one cannot be said to be free from the defilement of desire.
As for the realms being mixed up,
it means that they would be both the desire realm and the formless realm.
Then one cannot say that the desire realm and the formless realm are different.
As for not being able to say one is free from the defilement of desire,
it means that when one is free from the craving of the desire realm, one is not said to be free from the defilement of the desire realm.
When one is free from the craving of the formless realm, one is said to be free from the defilement of the desire realm.
This is unreasonable.
Why do the latent afflictions in the form realm not increase in the dharmas of the desire realm?
Answer: The realms would be mixed up.
And because they are not the objects of that.
As for the realms being mixed up,
it means that they would be both the form realm and the desire realm.
Then one cannot say that the form realm and the desire realm are different. As for because they are not the objects of that,
it means that the afflictions of the higher stages do not take the dharmas of the lower stages as objects.
Why do the latent afflictions of the form realm not increase in relation to the dharmas of the formless realm?
Answer: The realms would become mixed up.
And it cannot be established that one is free from attachment to form.
As for the realms becoming mixed up,
it means that [the form realm] would be both the form realm and the formless realm.
Then it cannot be said that the form and formless realms are different.
As for it not being able to be established that one is free from attachment to form,
it means that when one is free from craving for the form realm, it is not called being free from attachment to the form realm.
When one is free from craving for the formless realm, it is then called being free from attachment to the form realm.
This is unreasonable.
Why do the latent afflictions of the formless realm not increase in relation to the dharmas of the desire realm?
Answer: The realms would become mixed up.
And they are not the objects of this [formless realm].
Why do the latent afflictions of the formless realm not increase in relation to the dharmas of the form realm?
Answer: The realms would become mixed up.
And they are not the objects of this [formless realm].
All should be understood as above.
Question: How are the three realms established?
Is it based on realm, based on place, or based on the cessation of craving?
If so, what is the problem?
If it is based on realm, it should be said that there are nine realms, because there are nine realms.
Namely, the desire realm, the four meditations, and the four formless [absorptions].
If it is based on place,
it should be said that there are forty realms, because there are forty places.
Namely, twenty places in the desire realm,
sixteen places in the form realm,
and four places in the formless realm.
If it is based on the cessation of craving,
it should also be said that there are nine realms.
Namely, the craving of the desire realm up to the craving of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception,
because each has a different scope.
The answer is: It should be said that the three realms are established based on the cessation of craving.
If so,
it should establish nine realms.
The answer is: The three realms are only established because craving of the same type is eliminated.
Namely, from the AvÄ«ci hell up to the Paranirmita-vaÅ›avartin heaven, all are established as the desire realm because they are differentiated by the craving of desire.
From the BrahmakÄyika heaven up to the Akaniá¹£á¹­ha heaven,
All are established as the form realm due to the distinctions of desire for form.
From the sphere of infinite space up to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception are all established as the formless realm due to the distinctions of desire for the formless.
Furthermore, if a place has form and desire, it is established as the desire realm.ğŸ”½Having form but no desire is established as the form realm.
Having no form and no desire is established as the formless realm.
Furthermore, if a place has form and a second [factor], it is established as the desire realm.
Having form but no second [factor] is established as the form realm.
Having no form and no second [factor] is established as the formless realm.
Furthermore, if a place has form and objects, it is established as the desire realm.ğŸ”½Having form but no objects is established as the form realm.
Having no form and no objects is established as the formless realm.
Furthermore, if a place has form and the requisites, it is established as the desire realm.
Having form but no requisites is established as the form realm.
Having no form and no requisites is established as the formless realm.
Furthermore, if a place has form, desire, and the grasping of self, it is established as the desire realm.
Where there is form and desire but the view of self is present, that is established as the form realm.
Where there is no form, no desire, but the view of self is present, that is established as the formless realm.

Furthermore, where there is form and a second view of self is present, that is established as the desire realm.ğŸ”½Where there is form but no second view of self is present, that is established as the form realm.
Where there is no form and no second view of self is present, that is established as the formless realm.
The same can be said for objects and requisites.

Furthermore, where there is form and shamelessness and lack of conscience are present, that is established as the desire realm. Where there is form but shamelessness and lack of conscience are not present, that is established as the form realm.
Where there is no form and shamelessness and lack of conscience are not present, that is established as the formless realm.

Furthermore, where there is form and stinginess and jealousy are present, that is established as the desire realm.ğŸ”½Where there is form but stinginess and jealousy are not present, that is established as the form realm.
Where there is no form and stinginess and jealousy are not present, that is established as the formless realm.
Furthermore, where there is form and the faculties of sorrow and suffering are present, that is established as the desire realm.
Where there is form but the faculties of sorrow and suffering are not present, that is established as the form realm.
The formless realm is established as not corresponding to the faculties of sorrow and suffering in the formless realm.

Moreover, if there is form, coarse food, and sexual desire corresponding, it is established as the desire realm.ğŸ”½If there is form, coarse food, but sexual desire does not correspond, it is established as the form realm.
If there is no form, coarse food, and sexual desire does not correspond, it is established as the formless realm.
Moreover, if there are the five aggregates as the cause of retribution and the five aggregates as the effect of retribution,
and unwholesome and indeterminate latent afflictions increase, it is established as the desire realm.
There are the five aggregates as the cause of retribution and the five aggregates as the effect of retribution,
but only indeterminate latent afflictions increase, it is established as the form realm.
There are the four aggregates as the cause of retribution and the four aggregates as the effect of retribution,
but only indeterminate latent afflictions increase, it is established as the formless realm.
Moreover, if there are the four aggregates as the cause of retribution and obtain one fruit,
and unwholesome and indeterminate latent afflictions increase, it is established as the desire realm.
There are the five aggregates as the cause of retribution and obtain one fruit,
but only indeterminate latent afflictions increase, it is established as the form realm.
There are four aggregates that are the cause of karmic retribution and obtain one fruit.
Only the indeterminate latent afflictions increase, establishing the formless realm.
Next, if there are three feelings that are the cause of karmic retribution and three feelings that are the fruit of karmic retribution,
unwholesome and indeterminate latent afflictions increase, establishing the desire realm.
There are two feelings that are the cause of karmic retribution and two feelings that are the fruit of karmic retribution.
Only the indeterminate latent afflictions increase, establishing the form realm.
There is one feeling that is the cause of karmic retribution and one feeling that is the fruit of karmic retribution.
Only the indeterminate latent afflictions increase, establishing the formless realm.
Next, if there are five feelings that are the cause of karmic retribution and four feelings that are the fruit of karmic retribution,
unwholesome and indeterminate latent afflictions increase, establishing the desire realm.
There are three feelings that are the cause of karmic retribution and three feelings that are the fruit of karmic retribution.
Only the indeterminate latent afflictions increase, establishing the form realm.
There is one feeling that is the cause of karmic retribution and one feeling that is the fruit of karmic retribution.
Only the indeterminate latent afflictions increase, establishing the formless realm.
Furthermore, if there is a place where there is a cause of form and formless karmic maturation and a result of form and formless karmic maturation,
and unwholesome and indeterminate latent afflictions increase, it is established as the desire realm.
There is a cause of form and formless karmic maturation and a result of form and formless karmic maturation,
and only indeterminate latent afflictions increase, it is established as the form realm.
There is a cause of formless karmic maturation and a result of formless karmic maturation,
and only indeterminate latent afflictions increase, it is established as the formless realm.
Just as there is form and formless, so too
the seen, unseen, resistant, and unresisting are explained in the same way.
Question: How are the three realms that have been explained established?
Are they stacked up above and below?
Or are they arranged side by side?
If they are above and below,
how can one be said to be completely free from attachment to them?
How can spiritual powers reach them everywhere?
If they are arranged side by side,
how can we understand the statement by Dharadatta?
It says, The worlds below are boundless, the worlds above are boundless.
Regarding this, some say:
They are stacked one above the other.
That is to say, below this world, far below the wind wheel in empty space, there is the highest heaven of the form realm below.
Below that, in turn, there is another highest heaven of the form realm, down to the wind wheel below that.
In this way, turning downward, the worlds below are boundless.ğŸ”½Moreover, above this world, far above the wind wheel in empty space, there is a wind wheel above.
Above that, in turn, there is another highest heaven of the form realm, up to the highest heaven of the form realm above that.
Above that, there is another wind wheel, turning upward, up to the highest heaven of the form realm above that.
In this way, turning upward, the worlds above are boundless.
Question: If that is so,ğŸ”½how can one be said to be completely free from attachment to them?
How can spiritual powers reach them everywhere?
Answer: If one is free from attachment to one desire realm,
one is said to be free from attachment to all desire realms.
Because the characteristics are the same.
However, the spiritual powers produced based on the first concentration,
But one can only reach the desire realm and the Brahma world, not the others.
Because the abodes are different.
In this way, being free from the defilements of the form realm and manifesting spiritual powers based on other concentrations,
it is also like this as appropriate.
Other masters say:
They are arranged side by side in order.
Question: If that is so,
how can we understand what Dharadatta said?
Answer: He should have said:
The desire realm below is boundless.
The form realm above is boundless.
Here, the various abodes of the desire realm have the same latent tendencies.
The form and formless realms have different latent tendencies according to the level.
Question: Why do the various abodes of the desire realm have the same latent tendencies?
The form and formless realms have different latent tendencies according to the level?
Answer: The desire realm is an indeterminate realm, not a realm of cultivation, not a realm of detachment from defilements.
Here, afflictions are like a horse without a bridle running freely.
Therefore, all abodes have the same latent tendencies.
The form and formless realms are realms of concentration, realms of cultivation, realms of detachment from defilements.
Here, afflictions are like a horse with reins, turning without freedom.
Therefore, the latent tendencies of each stage are separate.
Moreover, in the desire realm, unwholesome roots are strong and wholesome roots are weak.
Therefore, in all places,
they are the same in terms of latent tendencies.
In the form and formless realms, there are no unwholesome roots, and wholesome roots are strong.
Therefore, the latent tendencies of each stage are separate.
Moreover, in the desire realm, unwholesome dharmas increase and wholesome dharmas decrease.
In the form and formless realms, there are no unwholesome dharmas and wholesome dharmas increase.
Moreover, in the desire realm, unwholesome dharmas are like a master.
Wholesome dharmas are like guests.
In the form and formless realms, there are no unwholesome dharmas.
Wholesome dharmas are like a master.
Moreover, in the desire realm, there are unwholesome roots that can sever wholesome roots.
In the form and formless realms, there are no unwholesome roots that can sever wholesome roots.
Moreover, in the desire realm, propriety is free from taboos, like a married couple.
Therefore, in all places, they are the same in terms of latent tendencies.
In the form and formless realms, etiquette is separated like mother and child.
Therefore, the latent tendencies are different in the upper and lower stages.
Furthermore, in the desire realm, the good dharmas of deportment are mixed.
It is like a prince and the son of an outcaste being imprisoned together.
Therefore, they have the same latent tendencies in all places.
In the form and formless realms, the good dharmas of deportment are not mixed.
It is like a prince and the son of an elder being imprisoned together.
Therefore, the latent tendencies are different in the upper and lower stages.
Question: Are there things in between the three realms or not?
If there are,
then there should be five realms with two things.
In the five in-between places, there are four things.
The realms should be nine.
In this way, it would be endless.
If there are not,
why do the three realms not combine to form one?
Answer: It should be said that there are no more things in between there.
Question: If so,
why do the three realms not become one?
Answer: Although there is no substance in between, it does not become one.
Like the eighteen elements, twelve sense bases, five aggregates, three times, four great elements, etc.
Although there is no substance in between, it does not become one.
This is also like that.
Furthermore, because the natures and characteristics are different and the categories of things are distinct,
although there is no substance in between, it does not become one.
Question: If that is so,
the distance between the Heaven of Free Enjoyment of Manifestations by Others and the lower level of the first dhyana is vast.
There is an immeasurable amount of space and form.
How can one know the distinction between the realms of desire and form?
Answer: At the edge of the two realms, there are both light and webs.
The two lights have different degrees of clarity and subtlety.
By this, one knows that this is the realm of desire and this is the realm of form.
Furthermore, if it is a place that can be seen by the heavenly eye obtained by one born in the realm of desire, it is the realm of desire.
A place that cannot be seen is the realm of form.
Furthermore, if it is a place that can be reached by the supernormal powers obtained by one born in the realm of desire, it is the realm of desire.
The places where they cannot reach are the form realm.
Furthermore, if a place is the object of desire realm craving, it is the desire realm.
The object of form realm craving is the form realm.
This is called the distinction in the extent of the two realms.
Why do the pervasive and non-pervasive latent afflictions in the desire realm not increase everywhere in the desire realm dharmas?
Answer: This should be pervasive, and those are not the objects of this.
This should be pervasive means:
The non-pervasive latent afflictions in this desire realm.
If they increase everywhere in the desire realm dharmas,
They should also be pervasive.
Then it would not be possible to establish the distinction in the characteristics and functions of the pervasive and non-pervasive latent afflictions.
And those are not the objects of this means:
The dharmas of other categories are not the objects of these non-pervasive latent afflictions.
This only takes the dharmas of its own category as objects.
Why is it so?
Because of the power of the non-pervasive latent afflictions,
The five categories of dharmas are established as different.
If the non-pervading proclivities also universally take the five categories as objects,
then they should universally increase in the five categories.
In this way, the five categories would become confused.
Because the five categories are confused, the antidotes would be confused.
Because the antidotes are confused, the direct realizations would be confused.
Because the direct realizations are confused, the distinctions of complete knowledge would be impossible.
The distinctions of the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a path.
One wishes to avoid such errors.
Therefore, the non-pervading proclivities of the desire realm do not universally increase in the dharmas of the desire realm.
Why do the non-pervading proclivities of the form realm
not universally increase in the dharmas of the form realm?
Answer: They should become pervasive.
And because they are not the objects of this [form realm].
Why do the non-pervading proclivities of the formless realm not universally increase in the dharmas of the formless realm?
Answer: They should become pervasive.
And because they are not the objects of this [formless realm].
All are explained as above.
The meaning of the omnipresent cause is explained in detail in the chapter on cognition in the Saá¹ƒyukta-Ägama.
The meaning of the omnipresent cause is explained in detail in the chapter on aggregates and the chapter on unwholesome aggregates in the Abhidharma-samuccaya.
There are ten kinds of thoughts, namely the thought of impermanence up to the thought of cessation.
This is explained in detail in the chapter on concentration in the Abhidharma-samuccaya.
If one cultivates the thought of impermanence, does one contemplate the thought of impermanence?
And so on, it is explained in detail.
There are four kinds of cultivation.
Namely, cultivation of attainment, cultivation of practice, cultivation of counteraction, and cultivation of removal.
The meaning of the four cultivations is explained in detail in the chapter on the knowledge of others' minds in the Abhidharma-samuccaya.
Among them, some say:
The treatise is made only based on the cultivation of practice.
Some say:
The treatise is made based on both the cultivation of attainment and the cultivation of practice.
Those who want to make the treatise here only based on the cultivation of practice,
they say that one who cultivates the thought of impermanenceğŸ”½means the thought of impermanence is present.
One who contemplates the thought of impermanence
means taking the thought of impermanence as the object.
It is when the contemplation of impermanence is present, contemplating the meaning of the contemplation of impermanence.
If one cultivates the contemplation of impermanence, does one contemplate the contemplation of impermanence?
The answer is: Four sentences should be made.
There is cultivation of the contemplation of impermanence without contemplating the contemplation of impermanence.
It means cultivating the contemplation of impermanence while taking other dharmas as objects.
Like taking the aggregates of form, feeling, perception, and consciousness as objects.
Except for the contemplation of impermanence, taking other aggregates of conceptualization as objects to give rise to the contemplation of impermanence.
Question: In what state is this explained?

Answer: In the state of increasing heat and peak, giving rise to the aspects of impermanence, the applications of mindfulness of body, feeling, mind, and dharmas, and taking other dharmas as objects, the application of mindfulness of dharmas.
If one is free from attachment to the desire realm up to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception,
giving rise to the aspects of impermanence, the applications of mindfulness of body, feeling, mind, and dharmas,
and taking other dharmas as objects, the application of mindfulness of dharmas as preparation.
At the time of the path of preparation, if one of unshakable faith sharpens one's faculties and becomes one who has attained view,
and if one of temporal liberation sharpens one's faculties and becomes immovable,
giving rise to the aspects of impermanence, the applications of mindfulness of body, feeling, mind, and dharmas,
and when taking other dharmas as the object, the dharmas as objects of mindfulness are the preparatory practice.
At the time of the preparatory path,
if one gives rise to the aspects of impermanence, and the mindfulness of body, mind, and dharmas,
and when taking other dharmas as the object, the dharmas as objects of mindfulness,
if one cultivates the formless concentrations by mixing this type of mindfulness with the dhyÄnas,
those who wish to make all dharmas ultimate,
when giving rise to this type of mindfulness and the unobstructed understanding of meaning,

and when giving rise to this type of mindfulness and the unobstructed understanding of eloquence, the knowledge of resolve, the concentration of the limit of the possible, the formless liberations, entering the concentration of cessation, the subtle mind of conceptualization,
at such times one cultivates the notion of impermanence.
Because the notion of impermanence is present.
Because one does not contemplate the notion of impermanence, taking other dharmas as the object.
There is contemplation of the notion of impermanence but not cultivation of the notion of impermanence.
It refers to taking the notion of impermanence as the object and cultivating other notions.
Other notions.
It refers to the notion of impermanence and suffering, the notion of suffering and non-self, and other wholesome, defiled, and indeterminate notions.
Among them, the wholesome notion.
It refers to wholesome [mental factors] that are preparatory.
And wholesome [mental factors] that are innate.
It refers to those accomplished through hearing, contemplation, and cultivation.
Those accomplished through hearing are as follows:
Regarding impermanence, one gives rise to the aspect of non-impermanence, which is accomplished through hearing.
Those accomplished through contemplation are as follows:
Regarding impermanence, one gives rise to the aspect of non-impermanence, which is accomplished through contemplation.
Those accomplished through cultivation are as follows:
Regarding impermanence, one gives rise to the aspect of non-impermanence.
Question: In what stage are these thoughts accomplished through cultivation said to be?
Answer: They are in the stages of heat, summit, patience, and increased growth.
Regarding impermanence, one gives rise to the aspect of non-impermanence, which is the application of mindfulness to dharmas.
If one is in the stage of the supreme worldly dharmas, one gives rise to the application of mindfulness to dharmas with three aspects.
If one has already entered the certainty of attaining nirvana and is in the four moments of the insight into suffering,
one gives rise to the application of mindfulness to dharmas with three aspects.
In the four moments of the insight into the origination and path,
one gives rise to the application of mindfulness to dharmas with four aspects.
If one uses the perception of impermanence but not the aspect of impermanence of the mindfulness of dharmas,
to become free from the defilements of the desire realm up to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception,
if one uses this very [perception of impermanence] as the preparatory stage,
at the time of all the preparatory, uninterrupted, and liberated paths,
if one uses the perception of impermanence but not the aspect of impermanence of the mindfulness of dharmas,
to sharpen one's faculties from being a faith-liberated one to a view-attained one,
to sharpen one's faculties from being a time-liberated one to an immovable one,
if one uses this very [perception of impermanence] as the preparatory stage,
at the time of all the preparatory, uninterrupted, and liberated paths,
if one uses the perception of impermanence but not the aspect of impermanence of the mindfulness of dharmas,
to cultivate the meditative absorptions and to give rise to the supernormal knowledge of others' minds and the supernormal knowledge of recollecting past lives,
when giving rise to the mindfulness of dharmas that uses the perception of impermanence but not the aspect of impermanence,
when giving rise to the four immeasurables,
those who wish to make all dharmas ultimate,
when giving rise to the unobstructed understanding of the meaning of this kind of mindfulness of dharmas,
And when giving rise to this type of dharma mindfulness, eloquence,
aspiration, wisdom, ultimate concentration, formless liberation, boundless space, consciousness, and everywhere, entering the concentration of cessation, the subtle mind of thought,
this is called good thought.
Defiled thought means
thinking of impermanence and giving rise to the view of a person,
grasping at self and what belongs to self and giving rise to the view of extremes,
grasping at annihilation and permanence and giving rise to wrong views,
grasping at no cause and no action and giving rise to the view of grasping,
grasping at the highest, wonderful, supreme and giving rise to the view of precepts and practices,
grasping at purity, liberation, and escape and giving rise to doubt and indecision,
giving rise to ignorance, lack of wisdom, darkness, and foolishness,
giving rise to craving, delight, and joy,
giving rise to aversion, lack of delight, and displeasure,
giving rise to pride and arrogance.
At such times, this is called defiled thought.
Neutral thought means
thinking of impermanence and giving rise to neither proper nor improper thoughts.
This is called contemplating the thought of impermanence.
Because one cultivates the thought of impermanence based on the thought of impermanence, one does not cultivate other thoughts.
There is cultivation of the thought of impermanence and also contemplation of the thought of impermanence.
That is to say, one cultivates the thought of impermanence based on the thought of impermanence.
When the thought of impermanence continues for a long time and appears in the present,
One contemplates the impermanence of one's own past and future continuity,
And the impermanence of the three times in the continuity of others.
Question: In what stage is this explained?
Answer: It is in the stage of heat, summit, patience, and increase.
One cultivates the thought of impermanence and the aspect of impermanence based on the mindfulness of dharmas.
If one cultivates the aspect of impermanence and the mindfulness of dharmas in the stage of the supreme worldly dharmas,
If one has already entered the certainty of the realization of suffering in the four moments,
One cultivates the aspect of impermanence and the mindfulness of dharmas.
If one uses the thought of impermanence and the aspect of impermanence of the mindfulness of dharmas,
One becomes detached from the desire realm up to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
If one uses this very [mindfulness of dharmas] as the preparatory practice,
At the time of the path of preparation, uninterrupted path, and liberation path for all of them.
If one of this type, using the application of mindfulness to dharmas, with faith and understanding, sharpens one's faculties to become one who has attained views,
and if one who is temporarily liberated sharpens one's faculties to become unshakable,
if one takes this very [application of mindfulness to dharmas] as the path of preparation,
at the time of the path of preparation, uninterrupted path, and liberation path for all of them.
If one of this type, using the application of mindfulness to dharmas, cultivates the meditative absorptions in combination,
and if there are those who wish to regard all dharmas as ultimate,
and gives rise to the unobstructed understanding of meaning,
and gives rise to the cognition of aspiration, the concentration of the limit of the formless liberations, enters the attainment of cessation, and the subtle mind of conceptualization,
some say.
and gives rise to the samÄdhi of the wishless wishless state,
at such times, one cultivates the perception of impermanence, because the perception of impermanence is present.
Also, one contemplates the perception of impermanence, because one takes the perception of impermanence as the object.
There are those who do not cultivate the perception of impermanence and also do not contemplate the perception of impermanence.
This refers to excluding the above characteristics.
Question: This is said to be in what state?
The answer is: in the stage of heat, summit, patience, and increased patience.
Arise with the mindfulness of dharmas that takes cessation as its object.
If one increases heat and summit, when one does not give rise to the mindfulness that takes impermanence as its aspect, but gives rise to the mindfulness that takes non-impermanence as its aspect.
If one has already entered the certainty of perfection, during the four moments of realizing cessation.
If, in the stage of cultivation, one is a post-learner.
When one gives rise to all mindfulness that does not take impermanence as its aspect, but takes non-impermanence as its aspect.
At such times, one does not cultivate the notion of impermanence.
Because the notion of impermanence does not manifest.
One also does not contemplate the notion of impermanence.
Because one does not take the notion of impermanence as an object.
The non-KaÅ›mÄ«ri masters outside of KaÅ›mÄ«ra say:
There are those who do not cultivate the notion of impermanence, nor do they contemplate the notion of impermanence.
That is, taking other dharmas as objects, one cultivates other notions.
For example, taking the aggregates of form, feeling, perception, and consciousness as objects, excluding the notion of impermanence.ğŸ”½One gives rise to other notions.
Taking the unconditioned as an object, one gives rise to other notions.
Other notions means:
Namely, the contemplation of impermanence, suffering, and no-self in suffering.
And all other contemplations that are not impermanence.
It should be known in detail as explained in the contemplation of impermanence.
The contemplation of impermanence in suffering and the contemplation of no-self in suffering are also like this.
The difference is:
Stating one's own name.

And in the third sentence, all except the contemplation of no-aspiration and the contemplation of impurity of no-aspiration, the contemplation of disgust with food, the contemplation of the undesirability of the entire world, the contemplation of death, the contemplation of cutting off, the contemplation of separation, and the contemplation of cessation.
What should be known according to circumstances?
It means if one cultivates the contemplation of impurity,
one does not contemplate the contemplation of impurity.
Because when the contemplation of impurity is present, it takes form and color as its object.
If one contemplates the contemplation of impurity,
one does not cultivate the contemplation of impurity.
Because when taking the contemplation of impurity as its object, other contemplations are present.
Other contemplations means:
The contemplation of impermanence, the contemplation of suffering in impermanence, and the contemplation of no-self in suffering.
And other wholesome, defiled, and indeterminate contemplations.

The same applies to the contemplation of impurity, the contemplation of the repulsiveness of food, the contemplation of the impermanence of all conditioned things, the contemplation of the unsatisfactoriness of all conditioned things, the contemplation of the selflessness of all things, the contemplation of death, the contemplation of abandonment, the contemplation of separation, and the contemplation of cessation.
The difference is:
It is said that each has its own object.
If one cultivates the contemplation of the repulsiveness of food,
one does not contemplate the contemplation of the repulsiveness of food.
Because when that contemplation is present, it takes smell, taste, and touch as its object.
If one contemplates the contemplation of the repulsiveness of food,
one does not cultivate the contemplation of the repulsiveness of food.
Because when taking that contemplation as its object, another contemplation is present.
The other contemplations are as explained above.ğŸ”½If one cultivates the contemplation of the impermanence of all conditioned things,
one does not contemplate the contemplation of the impermanence of all conditioned things.
Because when the contemplation of the impermanence of all conditioned things is present, it takes the impermanent conditioned things as its object.
If one contemplates the impermanence of all conditioned things,
one does not cultivate the contemplation of the impermanence of all conditioned things.
Because when taking that contemplation of the impermanence of all conditioned things as its object, another contemplation is present.
The other thoughts are as explained above.
If one cultivates the thought of death, one does not contemplate the thought of death.
Because when the thought of death is present, it takes as its object the life faculty and the impermanence nature that arises together with the life faculty.
If one contemplates the thought of death, one does not cultivate the thought of death.
Because when taking the thought of death as its object, other thoughts are present.
The other thoughts are as explained above.
If one cultivates the thought of cessation, one does not contemplate the thought of cessation.
Because when the thought of cessation is present, it takes nirvÄá¹‡a as its object.
If one contemplates the thought of cessation, one does not cultivate the thought of cessation.
Because when taking the thought of cessation as its object, other thoughts are present.
The other thoughts are as explained above.

the thought of extinction is also like this.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
